image.altText: Two women in an office look at a laptop.

items.synopsis: A surge in sales of homes purchased within the past two or three years has analysts and agents concerned the property market is rolling over as mortgage stress bites.

title.children: 'We need to sell': Why Australians are ditching homes they bought just a couple of years ago

image.altText: A shiny white and grey kitchen countertop.

items.synopsis: The reality is these shiny stone benchtops are not a necessity and too many of our tradies who work with them are getting sick or dying, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Kitchen benches are still killing young tradies — and we know how to stop it

image.altText: A middle-aged woman with blonde hair, sunglasses and a dark cap smiles holding a box of keepcups labelled 'walking cups'.

items.synopsis: There isn't a whole lot of consistency in Australia around what single-use plastics are being phased out and when. See what's happening in your state.

title.children: Single-use plastic coffee cups are being banned in some states. What's happening where you live?

image.altText: MCU of Wally Lewis wearing dark suit, white shirt and purple tie

items.synopsis: Your place for today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Wally Lewis reveals probable CTE diagnosis as Missing Person's Week launches. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Missing Persons Week 2023 has launched with NSW Police announcing this year the State Crime Command's Missing Persons Registry has received 42 reports, and 20 confirmed reports, of unidentified bodies and human remains found in NSW. Of those 20 confirmed reports, the Missing Persons Registry has identified nine through varying investigative techniques, including advancements in DNA. Six of those remain subject of ongoing investigations. Those six unidentified remains were found in various parts of NSW: from Kiama to Moree and Byron Bay.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 42 reports of unidentified bodies found in NSW this year

image.altText: A woman wearing a long, purple gown on the red carpet

items.synopsis: Sonia Kruger takes home the most prestigious award in Australian television, winning the 2023 Gold Logie in Sydney on Sunday.

title.children: 'I cannot believe that, I have to compose myself': Sonia Kruger shocked to win 2023 Gold Logie

image.altText: A composite image of a woman and a man holding awards in their hands

items.synopsis: The 2023 Logie Awards saw some rather unexpected wins and heartfelt tributes. These were the biggest moments of the night.

title.children: Unforeseen wins and tributes were among the biggest 2023 Logie Awards moments

image.altText: Matildas star Sam Kerr frowns as she talks with a team coachduring a training session.

items.synopsis: A decision on whether superstar Sam Kerr can play in the Matildas' must-win Women's World Cup game against Canada will be a late call, according to coach Tony Gustavsson.

title.children: Availability of Kerr to 'go down to the wire', says Matildas coach, admitting missing out on knockout stages would be a 'failure'

image.altText: Three Australian female football players look upset, one covers her face, after defeat in a World Cup match.

items.synopsis: Australia failed to take their chances against Nigeria. With everything now on the line, will they risk it all against Canada?

title.children: Can the Matildas rescue their Women's World Cup campaign?

image.altText: Seen through glass, a woman looks annoyed with raised hand, facing another person, visible from behind.

items.synopsis: More than simply being annoying, difficult people can impact your psychological safety, argues expert Rebecca Ray. But their power can be diminished.

title.children: From energy vampires to boundary violators, difficult people are everywhere. Here's how to handle them

image.altText: David Warner squints as he plays a cross bat shot that sends the ball into the air

items.synopsis: A period of brilliant batting and some timely rain gives Australia hope of achieving something remarkable on the last day of this Ashes series, and David Warner is central to the drama.

title.children: As defiant as ever, David Warner earns the chance to become Australia's Ashes hero

image.altText: A smiling mother sits in her kitchen and holds her baby.

items.synopsis: A new survey involving hundreds of Australian parents finds workplaces aren't communicating with staff while on parental leave, and are changing their jobs without consultation.

title.children: Workers are monitored, excluded, have fewer opportunities after parental leave, study shows

image.altText: Ambulance at the scene of an explosion in Pakistan.

items.synopsis: A powerful bomb rips through a rally of supporters for a hard-line cleric and political leader, police say.

title.children: Pakistan political rally explosion kills at least 40, with nearly 200 injured

image.altText: A middle-aged man in dark suit speaks at podium in front of Australian and US flags

items.synopsis: American military analysts will be sent to work at the Defence Intelligence Organisation in Canberra to scrutinise the moves of states like China, Russia and North Korea in the region, Defence Minister Richard Marles has announced.

title.children: US military spies to embed in Australia's defence department to monitor regional threats

image.altText: A man in a navy blue suit.

items.synopsis: The inquiry, which began in mid-April, was sparked by a letter from the ACT's top prosecutor, claiming police pressured him not to charge Mr Lehrmann and alleging political interference.

title.children: Inquiry's report into prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann to be handed to government today

image.altText: Woman lifting the lid of a funeral urn.

items.synopsis: From firing them into the night sky, to letting fly at the SCG, to tossing them at Pink, people are finding creative ways to scatter ashes — but what are the do's and don'ts when it comes to farewelling your loved one's remains?

title.children: Ever wondered where you can scatter a person's ashes? Here are a few things you might want to think about

image.altText: Stuart Broad walks with James Anderson

items.synopsis: The penultimate day of the Ashes starts with a tribute to retiring Stuart Broad, before some wild bowling and solid Aussie batting sets up a grand finale. Here are five things you missed from The Oval overnight.

image.altText: The moment a Ukrainian drone hit a building in Moscow.

items.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says that "war is returning to the territory of Russia" after two drones crashed into Moscow's city business district.

image.altText: A man sits between two women, with all three looking sad.

items.synopsis: Joanne Woods has lost count of the loved ones her community has lost to suicide in WA's Great Southern region, as she and advocates call for urgent change to stop more people dying.

image.altText: four images of four different men superimposed over an image of a still ocean

items.synopsis: Captain Danniel Lyon, Lieutenant Maxwell Nugent, Warrant Officer Class Two Joseph Laycock and Corporal Alexander Naggs were on board the MRH90 helicopter that ditched into the ocean during a training exercise as part of Exercise Talisman Sabre.

image.altText: A Whole New Ballgame | David Pocock

items.synopsis: Independent senator David Pocock says the federal government should be given a duty of care to protect young people from climate change when assessing fossil fuel projects.

image.altText: Photo of cattle in a cattle yard.

items.synopsis: Indonesia stops importing live cattle from four Australian exporters following disease detection.

title.children: Indonesia reports lumpy skin disease in cattle imported from Australia

image.altText: An Australian netball player looks behind her as she grabs the ball in mid-air, with Fijian defenders chasing her.

items.synopsis: The Diamonds record their largest victory at the Netball World Cup so far against Fiji, as troubled Collingwood shooter Sophie Garbin proves her selection was warranted.

title.children: Australia cracks the 100, as Sophie Garbin silences the doubters at Netball World Cup

image.altText: A red F1 car cuts across an orange F1 car, forcing its right front tyre into a barrier

items.synopsis: Oscar Piastri fumes at Ferrari's Carlos Sainz after a crash on lap 1 ends his race.

title.children: 'Like I didn't exist': Piastri fumes at Ferrari rival after lap 1 crash

image.altText: David Warner looks at the ball bouncing as he prepares to take off for a run

items.synopsis: Rain brings an early conclusion to proceedings on day four of the fifth Ashes Test at The Oval, but not before David Warner and Usman Khawaja combine to give Australia hope of victory.

image.altText: A heavily built, unsmiling man wearing a suit and tie.

items.synopsis: Italy made an "improvised and atrocious" decision when it joined China's Belt and Road Initiative four years ago as it did little to boost exports, Italian Defence Minister Guido Crosetto says in an interview.

title.children: Italy's defence minister says joining China's Belt and Road initiative was 'atrocious' decision

image.altText: Margo Wiltens stands on a beach vollyball court and stands ready to spike a ball.

items.synopsis: "We need women and young girls to see female coaches, to believe that they too can achieve positions of responsibility and influence."

title.children: Paris 2024 will be first Olympics to achieve gender parity among athletes, but there's still a long way to go

image.altText: A composite image of three people wearing different coloured dresses on a red carpet

items.synopsis: We've seen everything from plastic waste gowns to Renaissance-inspired suits — these are the breakout looks we saw on the 2023 Logies red carpet.

title.children: Logies red carpet: Gowns made out of garbage and glowing neon frocks

image.altText: Two German players block out a Colombian.

items.synopsis: The hearts of home fans are broken after New Zealand can't score the goal that would have taken them through to the knockout stages as they draw 0-0 with Switzerland in Dunedin.

title.children: New Zealand eliminated from home World Cup at group stage, Colombia stun Germany

image.altText: A man in army fatigues stands in front of the Ukrainian flag

items.synopsis: The Ukrainian President has proved a curse for Russia, uniting his nation while garnering western support for his cause. But how good a military strategist is he? And to what extent has he held his side together, asks John Lyons.

title.children: What makes Zelenskyy an 'exceptional' leader, according to four experts who've seen him up close and personal

image.altText: a mother holds her baby daughter high in the air, they are both looking at each other and smiling

items.synopsis: Samantha's first child died at two days old. Before she had even seen him, a specialist told her she would never be able to have another pregnancy.

title.children: Samantha was told a second pregnancy could kill her. She decided the risk was worth it
